name: Tokyo
fun_fact: Fun fact: Tokyo has more Michelin stars than Paris and New York COMBINED, yet some of the best food comes from tiny hole-in-the-wall joints and street stalls. The city has 5+ million vending machines selling everything from hot canned coffee to mystery items wrapped in white paper. Tsukiji Market handled over 2,000 tons of seafood daily before moving to Toyosu in 2018.

hero_dishes.name: Edomae Sushi
hero_dishes.description: Tokyo's original sushi style using fish from Tokyo Bay (Edo Bay). Fresh seafood is salted, vinegar-pickled, steamed, boiled, or marinated to intensify flavors - not just served raw.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originated in late Edo period (around 1800). 'Edomae' means 'in front of Edo' referring to Edo Castle and Tokyo Bay. These preservation techniques were developed before refrigeration, creating deeper, more complex flavors than modern sushi.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tsukiji Outer Market sushi stalls, high-end sushi restaurants in Ginza, traditional Edomae specialists throughout Tokyo

hero_dishes.name: Monjayaki
hero_dishes.description: Tokyo's runny pancake - a liquid batter mixed with cabbage, seafood, and meat, cooked on a hot grill. You scrape it off the grill with a small spatula and eat it directly.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A distinctly Tokyo dish, especially associated with the Tsukishima neighborhood. It's more casual and playful than okonomiyaki - the cooking process is interactive and social.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Tsukishima's 'Monjayaki Street' (dozens of restaurants), izakayas in downtown Tokyo

hero_dishes.name: Chanko Nabe
hero_dishes.description: The protein-rich hot pot that fuels sumo wrestlers - fish or chicken with seasonal vegetables in a healthy, flavorful broth.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Sumo wrestlers eat this in huge quantities to build muscle and weight. Despite its association with size, it's actually very healthy and balanced.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Specialty restaurants around Kokugikan Sumo Stadium in Ryogoku (many run by ex-sumo wrestlers)

hero_dishes.name: Tsukemen
hero_dishes.description: Cold ramen noodles served with hot dipping soup - Tokyo's innovative take on ramen. The noodles are thick and chewy.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in Tokyo's Nakano ward. It's part of Tokyo's fierce ramen innovation - Ikebukuro, Shibuya, and Shinjuku are known as battlegrounds in the ramen scene.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ramen shops in Nakano, Shinjuku, Shibuya

signature_drinks.name: Highball (Whiskey & Soda)
signature_drinks.description: Japanese whiskey mixed with sparkling soda water and ice. Simple, refreshing, and insanely popular at every izakaya.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: It's standard to start with 'Toriaezu, biiru' (beer for now) then switch to highballs throughout the meal. The whiskey revival around 2000 made highballs a staple. Perfect with greasy izakaya food.

signature_drinks.name: Sake (Nihonshu)
signature_drinks.description: Rice wine brewed with water and koji mold. Besides major brands, there are countless local rice wines (jizake). Can be drunk hot, room temperature, or cold.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Temperature depends on the sake grade and season. Premium sake is usually chilled; cheaper sake is often warmed. Pair with sushi, grilled fish, and traditional Japanese dishes.

signature_drinks.name: Lemon Sour (Chu-hai)
signature_drinks.description: Shochu or vodka mixed with lemon juice and soda water. Refreshing, not too sweet, and especially popular with women.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At izakayas throughout the night. It's lighter than highballs and comes in many fruit flavors (ume, peach, grapefruit), but lemon is the classic.

signature_drinks.name: Nama Biiru (Draft Beer)
signature_drinks.description: Fresh draft beer - the customary way to start any izakaya meal in Japan.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Order immediately upon sitting down, even before looking at the menu. Say 'Toriaezu, biiru!' (Beer for now!). Everyone toasts with 'Kanpai!' before drinking.

food_culture_notes: Tokyo has more Michelin stars than any city in the world, but street food and tiny shops are equally revered
Slurping soba and ramen is encouraged - it's the best way to appreciate the aroma
Yokocho (narrow drinking alleys) like Golden-Gai, Omoide Yokocho in Shinjuku are where locals drink
Izakaya culture is about small plates, lots of drinks, and social bonding after work
It's common to order 'Toriaezu, biiru' (beer for now) before even looking at the menu
Tsukiji Outer Market still operates with 400+ shops selling fresh seafood and street food
5+ million vending machines throughout Tokyo sell hot and cold drinks, snacks, beer
Despite crowds, everyone walks and boards trains in orderly fashion
Most Japanese don't eat while walking (except at festivals) - food deserves full attention
Namiyoke Shrine at Tsukiji protects fishermen and market workers from waves

atmosphere: Narrow izakaya alleys packed with tiny bars
Neon signs reflecting on wet streets
colors: White and black (sushi rice and nori)
unique_modern: Conveyor belt sushi meeting fine dining
